thread.title: Falcons pull off first upset of HOIC tournament
thread.title_full: Falcons pull off first upset of HOIC tournament

author: Erich Murphy
title: Falcons pull off first upset of HOIC tournament
text: Falcons pull off first upset of HOIC tournament Heart of Illinois Conference volleyball tournament Comment   By Erich Murphy Posted Oct. 21, 2015 at 1:22 AM By Erich Murphy Posted Oct. 21, 2015 at 1:22 AM Lexington Flanagan-Cornell served notice that despite being seeded sixth, it was not going be a patsy. Indeed, the Falcons overcame a third set deficit to upset third-seeded Heyworth in the last quarterfinal match of the night Tuesday. The three-set victory vaulted Flanagan-Cornell into the semifinals of the Heart of Illinois Conference tournament. The Falcons will meet second-seed Tri-Valley Thursday. The Vikings defeated Tremont in the first quarterfinal. Also advancing to the semifinals was top-seed and defending state champion Dee-Mack, who handled El Paso-Gridley in the second quarterfinal. The fourth quarterfinal will take place Thursday with No. 4 Lexington facing No. 5 Fieldcrest in the 4:15 p.m. match. Flanagan-Cornell-Heyworth The Falcons rallied from a four-point deficit in the third set to get past Heyworth 25-13, 22-25, 18-16. It was a comeback that might be considered one of the best in the program’s history. “It was good to see us fighting to the end. It was a great finish,” Flanagan-Cornell head coach Kari Harms said. “Great” could be an understatement. The Falcons were down four at match point before charging back. Ashley Van Weelden delivered a kill, her first of the match, for a sideout to dodge the first match point by the Hornets. Alana Harms got the serve for Flanagan-Cornell recorded two points after two errors by Heyworth. A timeout came with the Hornets’ lead down to 14-13. Van Weelden made a block, one of her 8 in the match, to tie the set at 14-14. A set kill from Heyworth’s Amber Tomlin gave the Hornets a 15-14 lead and the serve. But Van Weelden’s final block of the night came when Mackenzie Koch’s tip was rejected at the net. This tied it at 15-15. Kelsi Scott’s second block of the set gave the Falcons a 16-15 lead. Heyworth stymied Flanagan-Cornell on its bid for the win with a sideout, but lost the serve when Ashley Farris, the leading hitter for the Falcons in the match recorded her ninth kill. Flanagan-Cornell made good on its second shot at match point when Madison Quattro’s attack went wide to send the Falcons into the semifinal round. Defense was the key as the Falcons blocked 10 attacks and dug up more than 20 Heyworth attacks. “I’m really pleased with the blocking tonight. We need to be stronger on defense and we’ve been focusing on that to complete our game,” Coach Harms said. “I thought Liberty (Vollmer) had some excellent and amazing digs. Ashley (Van Weelden) and Kelsi, even just touching it and slowing it up, the defense reacted well to the ball.” Page 2 of 3 - Flanagan-Cornell did not trail in the first set. Alana Harms served an ace to trigger a spurt that gave the Falcons a 17-8 lead. The first set ended when Sam Lyons’ tip landed for a kill. Heyworth did not trail in the second set, though there were ties at 1-1 and 2-2. Farris had 9 kills while Harms added 4 kills to go with 8 digs and 9 service points. Scott had 11 points from behind the serving line while Lyons collected 10 assists and Vollmer had 7 assists. Van Weelden had 8 blocks. Koch had 12 kills for Heyworth. The Hornets registered 28 kills for the match. Tomlin had 23 assists. Flanagan-Cornell-GCMS Flanagan-Cornell opened its tournament with a 25-16, 25-12 win over Gibson City-Melvin-Sibley. The match was not close as Van Weelden had 6 kills. Lyons had 11 assists and Vollmer contributed 8. Alyssa Allemand had 3 kills for GCMS. Lexington-Ridgeview There wasn’t going to be an upset in the first match of the tournament as the Minutemen shot past the Mustangs 25-6, 25-9. Ridgeview did hold a 2-1 lead in the first set but Lexington’s power game charged up. Gabby Freed had a kill for a sideout that tied it at 2-2. Freed added two more kills and Lauren Boyd had two as part of a six-point service run from Ashland Eckhart. After trading sideouts, Lexington’s Lexi Bury had a seven-point run that was highlighted by three aces and a pair of Freed kills. “It was a nice opener for us, to just get a feel for the tournament,” LHS head coach Julie Strating said. “We talked about trying to take charge of the match early on.” Freed finished with 7 kills in a match that allowed for plenty of players to take part. Bury had 13 assists and 9 points. Starr Baker made 9 digs. Mya Tinsley had 2 kills for the Mustangs. Fieldcrest-Fisher Hannah Peterson controlled the net play with 6 kills and 2 blocks in helping lead Fieldcrest to a 25-11, 25-8 win over Fisher. This was another match that was one-sided most of the way. The Bunnies did have a lead in the second set but the Knights were able to roll into the quarterfinals. “That second set, we were trying out some different options on serve receive,” FHS head coach Jennifer Bartman said. “After they got to point seven, the girls decided no more and they turned it on the swings started coming better. “I felt we were in control of the match the whole game.” Jaclyn Kalkwarf had 10 assists and Gwen Lohr-Fandel made 16 digs. Megan Nigg had 4 kills for the Bunnies. Page 3 of 3 - EPG-Dee-Mack As might be expected, Dee-Mack was in control of its quarterfinal match with El Paso-Gridley. The Chiefs won 25-7, 25-18 to move into the semifinal round. Ashley Melton was dominant at the net with 7 kills and 8 blocks for the Chiefs. Caitlynn Whitaker contributed 14 service points and Kenzie Rhodes had 11 assists. Shelby Fulk had 5 kills and Gracie Feeney made 12 assists while Jenna Rote led the Titans’ defense with 10 digs. EPG-LeRoy The Titans rolled in the first set against LeRoy but needed to rally in the second for the sweep, 25-13, 25-22. The Panthers led 20-14 in the second set when EPG made its move. The Titans tied it up at 21-21 and took a 22-21 lead off a backhanded tip from Aubrey Staton. The match was over a few plays later. “We’ve been working hard in practice on consistency,” EPG head coach Penny Grusy said. “We needed to go ahead and finish and they came through and did it. This group has never given up.” Staton finished with 6 kills and Feeney had 14 assists. Miranda Reeves served up 12 points and Rote made 6 digs. Other Matches Tri-Valley overpowered Tremont 25-13, 25-15 in the quarterfinal round to advance opposite Flanagan-Cornell. Ryleigh Warfel had 8 kills and Hannah Clayton made 4 blocks for the Vikings. Natalie Tagala had 18 assists and Jessie Jensen had 7 service points and 14 digs. Lauren Hartman had 4 kills, 7 digs and 2 blocks for Tremont. The Turks reached the quarters by getting past Blue Ridge 25-22, 25-11. Hartman had 7 kills, 5 blocks and 9 points. Katelyn Miller had 2 kills for the Knights. By Erich Murphy   By Erich Murphy
